details.title: A new model for repairable systems with bounded failure intensity
details.standardTitle: A new model for repairable systems with bounded failure intensity

p: Laura Attardi is currently a Contract Professor of Statistics and Probability at the University of Naples Federico II. She received her Doctor degree (1997) in environmental engineering, and a Ph.D. in total quality management (2002) from the University of Naples, Italy. Her major research interests are in extreme value theory, and statistical reliability modeling.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Aeronaut. Eng., Univ. Federico of Naples, Italy
authors.name: L. Attardi

p: Gianpaolo Pulcini is currently a Senior Researcher in the Department of Statistics and Reliability at the Istituto Motori of the National Research Council (CNR) of Italy, and an Adjoint Professor of Statistics and Reliability at the Parthenope University of Naples. He received his Doctor degree (1982) in aeronautical engineering from the Federico II University of Naples, Italy. His major research interests are in mechanical reliability modeling and related statistical topics, mainly oriented to the Bayesian statistics.

details.abstract: This paper proposes a new model, called the 2-parameter Engelhardt-Bain process (2-EBP) model, to describe the failure pattern of complex repairable systems subjected to reliability deterioration with the operating time, and showing a finite bound for the intensity function. The characteristics of the 2-EBP model are discussed, and the physical meaning of its parameters is derived. The 2-EBP model can be viewed as a dynamic power law process, whose shape parameter ranges from 2 to 1 as the system age increases, converging asymptotically to the homogeneous Poisson process. Maximum likelihood estimates of model parameters & other quantities of interest, as well as a testing procedure (based on the likelihood ratio statistic) for time trend, are provided. Numerical applications are given to illustrate the 2-EBP model & the related inferential procedures, and to emphasize on the caution to use in assuming the (very often used) power law process when the presence of a finite bound for the failure intensity is conjecturable.

context.text: Models able to describe such a behavior are several NHPP; among them, the log-linear process 1, and the PLP 2 are well known.

A goodness-of-fit test based on the modified Cramér-von Mises statistic 2 showed that the PLP assumption could not be rejected at 0.05 \$s\$-significance level, and then the PLP parameters \$a\$ & \$b\$ were estimated.

Each time the modified Cramér-von Mises goodness-of-fit test (e.g., 2, 11) did not reject the PLP assumption at 0.10 \$s\$-significance level, the \$s\$-expected number of failures in the future time interval \$(t_{n}, 2 \cdot t_{n})\$, say \$\mathhat{M}\$, has been estimated, and the number \$N\$ of pseudo-random failures occurring in the same interval has be counted.

links.abstract: Much of the recent work on modeling repairable systems involves Poisson processes with nonconstant intensity functions, viz, nonhomogeneous Poisson processes. Since times between failures are not identically distributed when the process is nonhomogeneous, it is not clear what concept should take the place of the mean time between failures in assessing the reliability of a repairable system. A number of alternate concepts can be found in the literature. We investigate the relationship between two...

context.text: Considering NHPP with an increasing bounded intensity function was first suggested by Engelhardt & Bain 5, but the mathematical simplicity of their 1-parameter model, called the EBP, makes it inadequate to analyze failure data in many cases.

This last result is in accordance with Theorem 1 of 5 because: \$a\$) the first failure time \$t_{1}\$ has finite mean (given by (9) by setting \$t_{i - 1} = 0\$), and \$b\$) the ratio \$[d\lambda (t)/dt]/[\lambda (t)]^{2}\$ tends to 0 as \$t\$ approaches infinity.
In addition, because \$\lambda (t)\$ is increasing, then \${\rm E}[w_{t}] \leq 1/\lambda (t)\$ 5.
